entry: October 25, 1910 SS. Kronprinz Wilhelm. Sailed this a.m. from New York at ten o'clock for Cherbourg and Paris. It seems an absurd route to take to Cairo – but the service of the Mediterranean steamers is so disorganized because of the cholera in so many infected ports, and the necessity of quarantine, that we cancelled our engagements for Naples. We will take the Schleswig at Marseilles, instead of Naples.

entry: Sunday, Oct. 30. We have had an uneventful stupid voyage, and are due at Cherbourg tomorrow. We have had rain, cold winds, and rough seas. Very pleasant rooms.

Sunday, Oct. 30.

entry: Paris – Oct. 31. Westminster Hotel. We made Plymouth at 7 o'clock this morning – I got up and looked out at the interesting coast – reached Cherbourg at 1 p.m. and were off at 3. We felt some little trepidation at committing ourselves to a French railway – there has been such a history of accidents in France! But we knew that this line had been thoroughly repaired – as was shown by the piles of the old sleepers all along the road – in the most astounding state of decay – utter rottenness – they gave damning evidence of neglect. I had never seen the Brittany country before. How charming those wide reaching fields were, in the late afternoon light – so softly green – and the characteristic, mostly pollarded trees in their tints of bronze and olive green and russet pink, made a picture, or rather a succession of them that looked as if they might have been painted by Troyon or Corot. It was a blissful afternoon – and we so enjoyed it. Arrived in Paris at 10 – and found Mr. Rathbone waiting for us. They are at the Bedford.

entry: Tuesday. Nov. 1st. It has poured with rain all day – have not been out of the house. It is All Saints Day, and every magasin and museum is closed. Mr. and Mrs. Rathbone and Elèna came to lunch, and are to turn up at the Gare de Lyon at 10. Mr. and Mrs. John E. Parsons are in this hotel, and we went to their rooms to have tea with them. We quite enjoyed our little dinner up in our sitting room. Hotels are crowded here – the manager told us there were more than 200 people in Paris waiting for a chance to cross the Mediterranean.

entry: N. G. Lloyd SS. Schleswig. Wednesday. Nov. 2nd. We had a rough night on our funny Wagon-Lit – and jolted through it with what patience we could – feeling as if we were travelling in a card-board box – arrived by 9 o'clock – found our old rooms ready for us – did not get off until nearly 5 o'clock – there being so many passengers and such piles of luggage.

entry: Monday. Nov. 7th. Shepheards Hotel. Arrived at 12:30 and were soon eating lunch on the 13th day out from New York! Surprising when one reflects that our steamers to Naples always take 13 days for the voyage! Are in our pleasant old rooms, overlooking the garden – the weather is perfect.

entry: Monday. Nov. 14th. Rather a busy week, settling ourselves and things on the boat, seeing sights – visiting and receiving friends – consulting Mr. Draper about the little mooring garden. Lunched one day with the Gorsts, and another day went to a reception there. Capt. Trefusis, and Mr. Carter BonhamMr. Bonham Carter, Elèna's friend, dined with us one night, and Mr. Lovatt and son – another night – and Mr. Lovatt and son and Mr. Walter Gay came to tea on our first afternoon on the boat. We had tea with the Gays one afternoon – Mrs. Gay very attractive.

entry: Monday. Nov. 21st. We came on board to stay on the 16th and sailed the next day at 10 a.m. passed the Ghizeh bridge about 10.20. We have a good strong tug. Tied up at 5 P.M. We find a tremendously big, wide river, with very strong current and made 35 miles the first day, 42 the second, 51 the third, 39 the fourth, 47 the 5th, 37 the 6th, 51 the seventh, 43 the eighth, 38 the ninth, 50-½ the tenth – arrived at Luxor the 27th. We tied up much in our usual place – to a mite of a sand bank, opposite the castle.

entry: Third Sunday in Advent. Dec. 11th. A rather busy week. Mr. Weigall and his sister Mrs. Rutter to tea one day. Mr. Nicol to dine – Mrs. Rutter and Mr. Weigall to dine. Theo has established Harry Burton in his new concession the "Priest Kings" Valley. M. Maspero was anxious Theo should clear this but Theo does not look for much of a result. Harold Jones is so poorly, so weak, quite incapable of work, even painting. But his brother Cyril keeps a certain supervision of the men. This afternoon Elèna, Theo and I rode over to see Mr. Carter and see some of Mr. Nicol's paintings – very lovely they were. Theo bought one.

entry: Fourth Sunday in Advent. Dec. 18th. Harold Jones and Cyril came over and spent 3 days at the Winter Palace, lunched twice with me. I gave tea at the Palace on day, and asked a few of Harold's friends – the poor fellow looked very tired when it was over. Baron v. Mumm called one afternoon – he is on his way back to China – he is the German minister of China. Mr. And Mrs. Gibson Fahnstock came to tea on Wednesday. We had for tea Miss Kelly and her brother, Mr. Whitaker and Mr. Whymper were here for tea. The Kellys played and sang.

entry: Christmas Day – Dec. 25th. We had the usual gifts for the sailors this morning – Harry Burton came this evening to stay until Wednesday morning. Walter Trefusis dined with us today.

entry: Saturday. Dec. 31st. We have had a cold week. Theo spent his usual 3 days in the Valley – nothing has yet been found. We have seen a good deal of Mr. Whitaker and his party. They are on the old Cleopatra – but he has done a great deal to it and put about a great many pretty things, and it looks very attractive. Mr. and Mrs. Newberry are with him, and they are to excavate somewhere near Akmim.

entry: Saturday. Jan. 28th. A rather cold stormy week, with a little rain. Mrs. Hunter of London dined on Monday – Mrs. and Miss Warner of Boston and Miss Webb, a Marquise Guadalmina and her son, Spaniards, here to tea on Wednesday. Theo and I at Mohassib's' one morning – met Miss Cassatt, the artist who lives in Paris. Mr. and Mrs. Kelekian came with her afterwards for tea. Mr. Nicol dined on Friday. Cold and stormy.

entry: Saturday. Feb. 11. Among our visitors this week were Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Alexander of 4 West 58 St. New York on the Serapis with their 3 girls; Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hobhouse of England introduced by Gaspard Farrer; Mr. and Mrs. Williams and Mr. and Mrs. Langley P.W.D. people of Cairo; Mr. and Mrs. GerardGiraud Foster of Lenox, Miss Ives and Mrs. Alexander of New York whose daughter lately married young Theodore Roosevelt; Mr. and Mrs. John Collander Livingston on the "Scarab". It has been bitterly cold lately – and constant high winds – we have been covered with sand – as the wind has been from the west. Theo came home from the Valley, after 4 days there.

Alexander of 4 West 58 St. New York on the Serapis with their 3 girls; Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hobhouse of England introduced by Gaspard Farrer; Mr. and Mrs. Williams and Mr. and Mrs. Langley P.W.D. people of Cairo; Mr. and Mrs. GerardGiraud Foster of Lenox, Miss Ives and Mrs. Alexander of New York whose daughter lately married young Theodore Roosevelt; Mr. and Mrs. John Collander Livingston on the "Scarab". emma_name: Mr. and Mrs. John Collander Livingston
entry: Sunday. Feb. 19th. A rather monotonous week of constant visitors. Amongst the most pleasant were Mr. and Mrs. John Collander Livingston, and daughter sent by Mrs. Hamilton Fish Webster. Delightful people. Our neighbors Mr. and Mrs. Auchincloss and Miss Jennings, M. and Mme. Naville and M. Rodier to dine. Mrs. and Miss Wherry, sisters of Mr. Cust, M. and Mme. Maspero and others. Theo and I had a charming afternoon with Mr. Carter in his new house – so well built and arranged and pretty – it looked like the abode of an artist and a scholar. He is just opening a large tomb or cachette for Lord Carnarvon – and when we had tea, he went back at once to his work. The Hon. Henry and Mrs. Hobhouse (from G. Farrer) dined with us this evening. Theo is to give them lunch in the Valley tomorrow.

Sailed at 7 A.M. – reached Nagh Hamadi at 12:15, passed the bridge and then waited until 3:30, waiting for the tug to cool – and reached Balliana at 5:30 where we wait until tomorrow – to give Elèna Rathbone a chance to see Abydos – and we promised the Navilles to lunch with them. It has been a fine, warm day – and our brilliant young moon, and the resplendent Venus, make the nights too beautiful to sleep.

entry: Monday. Mar. 6th. Started about 10 for Abydos – fearing a hot day – had 2 carriages – we found a cold north wind blowing, and we really suffered with cold. It was a market day, and the people were streaming along the dusty road – men, women carrying babies, camels, donkeys, sheep and goats – making the air thick with dust. It is such a pity that one must always see Abydos in the glare of mid-day! Mme. Naville came up from their little house in its nest in the sandy desert, to see us – and we all went back with her – I sitting on a man's saddle on a wretched donkey, – the cold wind almost blowing my clothes off – and my eyes blinded. But the little house was cheerful and comfortable and the lunch very good, and M. and Mme. Naville very nice as they always are. Mr. Whitmore and Mr. Dixon, young men working with the Navilles. The ride home was away from the wind, and the fields so green and fragrant with their blossoming crops, and the birds singing everywhere. The people were in their straw houses, which they build for watching their crops – and it was very pastoral. Found a huge mail waiting for us. We steamed down to Girga, 8 miles, and are here for the night.

entry: Wednesday. Mar. 8th. 52 miles. Arrived at Assiut early, and waited for various things – 4 hours – then on to 7 miles of Hadj Kandul.

entry: Thursday. March 9th. Started at 7 o'clock – stopped at Hadj Kandul for an hour so that Elèna should see the Khuenaton pavement, then on, until Beni Hassan was reached, which Elèna and Harry visited. The day hot – wind and clouds of dust. 43 miles.

entry: Saturday. Mar. 11th. 87 miles. An early start at 6 o'clock – and reached Bedreschein at 7 o'clock. The river has been rather good. The tug has been on the sand once or twice for a short time, but the dahabya has not once touched it – a strong wind all day and cold.

entry: Second Sunday in Lent. March 12th. Started at 7 o'clock – and made the bridge at 9 o'clock and waited an hour to pass. Came to our landing at 11.30 – and found the mooring garden looking very pretty. We arrived the 10th day from Luxor. Found telegram telling of Harold Jones' peaceful end on Thursday, the 9th.

entry: March 13th. Monday. Mr. Draper to lunch yesterday. At home all day – rather warm today. Elèna and I drove into town this morning – saw a number of friends – met Mr. Newberry at Deimer's, and he went with us to Kolekian's and to Kassera's – there Theo and Harry joined us, and we went to Nachman's. Elèna and Harry went after lunch to the Mena House, and Theo and I went for a drive – and finding ourselves, in spite of warm wraps, freezing in the cold wind, we came home.

entry: Wednesday. March 15th. Elèna and Harry made an early start for Sakkara – going by train to the Mena House, and taking donkeys for Sakkara They came back at 7 P.M. after a joyful day. Mr. Winlock appeared this morning at 10 – and made quite a visit – then he, Theo and I went to town, and to Kyticas's to see a lovely Greek statuette which Theo thinks of buying. Mr. and Mrs. Newberry and Mr. Johnson came to lunch, and we had such a pleasant visit. I went at 5 o'clock over to the Cleopatra to tea with the Whittakers – Lady Layard, and the 2 ladies staying with them, Mr. Johnson and Capt. Trefusis there. Coming home, I overtook Theo walking, and as the cold, cold wind had much moderated, and he got into the carriage, we drove around the island.

entry: Friday. Mar. 17. The morning was so very hot, that we did nothing but drive until 12 o'clock – when I left Theo at the boat, and I went to the Semeraine's HotelSemiramis Hotel to see Mrs. Duvar – she was not at home. I left a note for her. In the afternoon, Elèna went with Mr. Bonham-Carter to polo – Harry and Mr. Whymper to the Zoo, where Theo and I soon followed them – and had a lovely visit. Just as we came away, we met Artin Pasha, and Mr. Sayce, who said they had just been to the boat hoping to find us, so they came back all of them for tea, and a long visit, and much pleasant talk.

entry: Saturday. Mar. 18th. In the house all day – a severe gale began about 7 o'clock – and grew in violence – making a great knocking about of the boats along the shore – a small yawl disappeared just behind us – and a gyassa was wrecked near the bridge. Cairo could not be seen across the river, in the clouds of dust. In doors all day.
